Dear Courtney LYNN-SMITH Atkins:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Reevaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12324
Section • (2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
Description and assessment of all the following:
1

• (d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster
homes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There is a concern that a licensing renewal report did not reflect
accurate methods of discipline.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone on 1/14/2025. Foster
Parent stated Licensing Worker 1 came out to her home in June or
July of 2024 to complete a renewal assessment at which time she
told Licensing Worker 1 the middle school youth she had in the
home was demonstrating behavioral issues, so Foster Parent was
“putting her to work” doing things such as raking for about 30
minutes at a time. Foster Parent told Licensing Worker 1 this was
the only thing that worked with that youth; however, the renewal
report just stated Foster Parent 1 keeps the youth busy as a form
of behavior management and does not provide any details as to
what that means. Foster Parent stated Licensing Worker 1 did not
interview any of the youths during the renewal inspection, so they
were not asked about discipline in the home. Foster Parent stated
Licensing Worker 2 was completing a special evaluation on her
home during which the youths were asked about discipline used in
the home. Foster Parent was found in violation due to using the
raking as a form of behavior management. Foster Parent stated
Licensing Worker 1 was aware of this method of discipline, yet she
never told Foster Parent it was not acceptable.
Licensing Worker 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/15/2025. She reported being a licensing worker for 9 years. She
completed Foster Parent’s renewal home visit 7/10/2024.
Licensing Worker 1 stated all youths were either at school or
daycare so Licensing Worker 1 only spoke to Foster Parent. She
stated she asked Foster Parent about methods of discipline used
in the home and Foster Parent stated she utilizes, “keeping the
child busy.” Licensing Worker 1 reported she interpreted that to
mean doing activities. Licensing Worker 1 stated she asked Foster
Parent for clarification, but she does not recall how Foster Parent
responded. During a special evaluation on Foster Parent’s home,
it was reported by the youths in the home that physical chores
were being used as discipline.
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/16/2025. She stated she reviewed and approved Licensing
Worker 1’s renewal inspection report. She stated it was in the
2

report that Foster Parent utilized keeping the youths busy as a
form of discipline but there was nothing in the report alluding to
the use of physical chores as discipline. Licensing Supervisor
stated she has already spoken to the licensing workers about the
need to ask follow-up questions when foster parents and youths
provide vague answers to questions in the future. Licensing
Supervisor stated the use of chores as discipline came out during
an investigation in Foster Parent’s home when it was disclosed by
Foster Parent’s adult daughter, who lives outside of the home.
Licensing Worker 2 was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/16/2025. She stated, during a special evaluation on Foster
Parent’s home, she interviewed all 3 of the youths in the home
who talked about physical chores as discipline. She also spoke to
Foster Parent who openly discussed the use of physical chores as
discipline. Licensing Worker 2 stated Foster Parent lives in a
heavily wooded area so there are always a lot of leaves on the
property. She stated Foster Parent reported the youths will have to
rake 1-2 hours for not more than 3 nights in a row for behavior
management. A safety plan was developed with her in which
Foster Parent agreed to not making youths rake for more than 30
minutes at a time as discipline and the youth’s assigned worker
had to be contacted regarding the use of raking as discipline.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 7/22/2024 Foster Home Reevaluation completed by
Licensing Worker 1 and approved by Licensing Supervisor.
Under Section, the methods of discipline used by licensee
stated, “use of communication, keeping the child busy,
grounding, and time outs.”
• 12/6/2024 Special Evaluation Report completed by
Licensing Worker 2 and approved by Licensing Supervisor
in which concerns with Foster Parent’s use of sweeping the
driveway or raking leaves for “an excessive amount of time”
for the ten-year-old in the home. A safety plan was
developed stating that, if physical chores are used as
discipline, they will not have to work for longer than 30
minutes, not to exceed 1 hour a day for a total of two days.
If after two days there are still behaviors, Foster Parent will
reach out to foster care to discuss. Additionally, the kids will
be allowed bathroom breaks, breaks, and to eat.
Analysis A violation has been established as Licensing Worker 1 did not
ensure Foster Parent’s compliance with foster home licensing rule
400.9404(3) by not asking Foster Parent or the youths in the
home for an explanation of keeping youths busy as a form of
behavior management. Additionally, during a special evaluation,
3

when the youths and Foster Parent were asked about discipline in
the home, they openly discussed the use of physical chores.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Special evaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section • (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
Description noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must
do all the following:
• (c) Conduct an evaluation, in cooperation with child
protective services, when applicable, including all
necessary collateral contacts.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The worker did not have conversations with the children during a
special evaluation.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone on 1/14/2025. Foster
Parent stated Licensing Worker 1 came out to her home in June or
July of 2024 to complete a renewal assessment. Foster Parent
stated Licensing Worker 1 did not interview any of the youths
during the renewal inspection. Foster Parent stated Licensing
Worker 2 was completing a special evaluation on her home during
which the youths were asked about discipline used in the home.
Licensing Worker 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/15/2025. She stated Licensing Worker 2 completed the special
evaluation on the home and the youths were questioned during
that investigation.
Licensing Worker 2 was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/16/2025. She stated during a special evaluation on Foster
Parent’s home, she interviewed all 3 of the youths in the home as
well as Foster Parent’s daughter who recently moved out of the
home.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED.
• 12/6/2024 Special Evaluation Report completed by
Licensing Worker 2 and approved by Licensing Supervisor
in which interviews with all household members were
documented.
Analysis No violation is established as Licensing Worker 2 interviewed the
youths in the home during the special evaluation.
4

Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code License recommendation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325
Section • (3) Except for an original license, an agency shall
Description recommend to the department the issuance of a regular
license or the continuation of an active license only when
all rules are in compliance, or both of the following
conditions exist:
• (b) A written corrective action plan has been
developed. The plan must comply with all of the
following requirements:
• (i) Upon determining a rule noncompliance
that is correctable by the foster parent, the
agency must develop a written corrective
action plan with the foster parent on the form
prescribed by the department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The worker is not working with foster parent on a needed CAP.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone on 1/14/2025. She
stated the licensing worker previously assigned to Foster Parent
retired, so the home was reassigned to Licensing Worker 1. Foster
Parent stated Licensing Worker 1 never responds to her texts or
calls, so she has to reach out to her supervisor who just tells
Foster Parent Licensing Worker 1 is busy and/or in training. Foster
Parent stated Licensing Worker 1 is supposed to be working on
developing a CAP with Foster Parent 1 as a result of special
evaluation findings. Foster Parent stated she agreed to completing
a psychological evaluations, counseling, and training as a part of
the CAP, but Foster Parent is requesting the training be virtual as
opposed to in person due to Foster Parent’s busy schedule.
Foster Parent stated Licensing Worker 1 told her if her schedule is
too busy, maybe she shouldn’t be a foster parent rather than
allowing virtual training.
Licensing Worker 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/15/2025. Licensing Worker stated a special evaluation on Foster
Parent’s home was completed by Licensing Worker 2. Licensing
Worker 1 has been trying to develop a CAP that resulted from that
special evaluation, but Foster Parent initially stated she just
5

wanted to close her license. Licensing Worker 1 was attempting to
coordinate the CAP requirements with the requirements of a
different MDHHS investigation, but Foster Parent was not
complying with those requirements. Licensing Worker 1 stated she
has been negotiating the CAP with Foster Parent by phone and
they agreed on the psychological evaluation and potential
counseling, but Foster Parent wanted to do training virtually.
Licensing Worker 1 wanted the training to be in person so
someone could physically evaluate Foster Parent’s progress.
Licensing Worker 1 stated during an MDHHS Worker’s
investigation, it came out that Foster Parent’s daughter was
watching the foster children most of the time due to Foster Parent
being away from the home until 7:30-8PM. Licensing Worker 1
told Foster Parent that fostering might not be in her best interest
because her schedule is too busy to allow her to be with the
youths and too busy to allow her to complete in person training.
Licensing Worker 1 stated they eventually agreed on weekend in-
person training.
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/16/2025. Licensing Supervisor reported also supervising the
MDHHS staff who provides ongoing services as a result of a
separate investigation in Foster Parent’s home and Foster Parent
was refusing to participate in all services. The initial CAP
developed in response to the special evaluation completed by
Licensing Worker 2 coordinated the other services provided, but
since Foster Parent was refusing those, Licensing Worker 1 was
attempting to work with Foster Parent to develop a CAP she would
agree to. Licensing Worker 1 talked to Foster Parent about
participating in psychological evaluation and training, but Foster
Parent is quick to say she wants to close her license as opposed
to completing a CAP. Licensing Supervisor stated Foster Parent
reached out to her by email stating Licensing Worker 1 was not
responsive to her. Licensing Supervisor stated Foster Parent’s
prior worker was an “over the top communicator” and Foster
Parent was used to at least weekly communication. Licensing
Supervisor stated she doesn’t have any concerns with Licensing
Worker 1’s communication with Foster Parent and Licensing
Supervisor is now copied on all emails between Licensing Worker
1 and Foster Parent, so she knows she is responsive and working
with Foster Parent.
Licensing Worker 2 was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/16/2025. She reported, in early December 2024, Licensing
Worker 2 sent Foster Parent a copy of her reports and let her
know Licensing Worker 1 would be following up with her to
6

develop a CAP. Licensing Worker 2 stated she hasn’t heard from
Foster Parent since.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 12/6/2024 Special Evaluation Report completed by
Licensing Worker 2 and approved by Licensing Supervisor
documenting a CAP is required.
• Pending CAP created 1/13/2025
Analysis No violation is established as Foster Parent and Licensing Worker
1 reported attempts to agree on CAP requirements.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Reevaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12324
Section • (2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
Description and assessment of all the following:
• (d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster
homes.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Licensing Worker did not interview each member of the household
for the reevaluation.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone on 1/14/2025. Foster
Parent stated Licensing Worker 1 came out to her home in June or
July of 2024 to complete a renewal assessment. Foster Parent
stated Licensing Worker 1 did not interview any of the youths
during the renewal inspection.
Licensing Worker 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/15/2025. She completed Foster Parent’s renewal home visit on
7/10/2024. Licensing Worker 1 stated all of youths were either at
school or daycare so Licensing Worker 1 only spoke to Foster
Parent. She stated she only speaks to all the household members
if they are home at the time of the renewal inspection.
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/16/2025. She stated she reviewed and approved Licensing
Worker 1’s renewal inspection report. She stated the 1 & 3-year-
olds in the home were not interviewed, and she did not know why
the interviews did not occur, but the older two youths were
interviewed.
7

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 7/22/2024 Foster Home Reevaluation completed by
Licensing Worker 1 and approved by Licensing Supervisor.
Within Section 8 of the report regarding summarizing
interviews with each member of the household, the only
interview documented is with Foster Parent, despite there
being five youths in the home (foster parent’s daughter and
4 foster children.)
Analysis A violation is established as Licensing Worker 1 did not interview
all household members to determine compliance with licensing
rules during reevaluation.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
